Subject: Olympus Capital Asia V, L.P. Fund, a Cayman Islands exempted limited partnership, is a close-ended private equity fund with a target capitalization of $750 million, which will invest in middle-market companies across the agribusiness and food, financial and business services, and environmental sectors in Asia.The report and recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors (RRP) document describes the terms and conditions of a project for consideration and approval by ADB's Board of Directors.This document dated November 2014 is provided for the ADB regional project 48343-001.
Title: Olympus Capital Asia V, L.P. Fund: Report and Recommendation of the President

A. 

 
 
 

I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed equity 

1. 
investment of up to $40,000,000 in the Olympus Capital Asia V, L.P. Fund. 1  
 

II. 

THE FUND 

Investment Identification and Description 

2. 
Description.  Olympus  Capital  Asia  V,  L.P.  Fund,  a  Cayman  Islands  exempted  limited 
partnership, is a close-ended private equity fund with a target capitalization of $750 million, which 
will invest in middle-market companies across the agribusiness and food, financial and business 
services, and environmental sectors in Asia. 2 The general partner (GP) will be Olympus Capital 
Asia  V  GP,  L.P.,  a  Cayman  Islands  exempted  limited  partnership.  The  Fund  will  have  an 
investment  management  agreement  with  Olympus  Capital  Holdings  Asia,  a  Cayman  Islands 
company and a registered investment advisor with the United States Securities and Exchange 
Commission. 3 
 
3. 
Investment identification. As part of its ongoing market mapping exercise of attractive 
private equity fund investment opportunities within ADB’s developing member countries (DMCs), 
the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  identified  Olympus  Capital  as  one  of  the  leading  private 
equity  firms  investing  in  middle-market  companies  in  Asia.  In  October  2013,  ADB  initiated 
dialogue with Olympus Capital and over the subsequent months followed the firm’s platform with 
increasing  interest  since  Olympus  Capital  operates  in  several  verticals  that  align  with  ADB’s 
mandate, and follows a specialized multi-sector investment strategy not commonly found among 
other  middle-market  private  equity  funds,  which  typically  have  a  country-specific  or  generalist 
approach. ADB was also attracted to Olympus Capital’s significant record of generating attractive 
co-investment opportunities for its limited partners, particularly in underserved sectors that ADB 
is keen to support, such as agribusiness and financial services. 
 
4. 
Based on the screening process of funds operating in the firm’s three core verticals, ADB 
ranked  Olympus  Capital  very  highly,  with  significant  competitive  advantage  over  its  direct 
competitors in terms of performance record, regional reach (including a sizeable regional platform 
with local teams), sector experience, access to direct proprietary deal flow, and investor base. 
Consequently,  ADB  considers  the  fund  to  be  a  high-quality  investment  opportunity  for  ADB’s 
private equity portfolio. 4  
 
B. 

Business Overview and Strategy 

 

5. 
The fund’s three core sectors (agribusiness and food, financial and business services, and 
environmental sectors) represent attractive areas for middle-market private equity investment in 
Asia since they continue to benefit from the rise in domestic consumption, particularly the shift to 
higher quality food and services; a growing middle class driving greater focus on food safety and 

 

1  Design and Monitoring Framework (included in Appendix 1). 
2  A middle market company is defined broadly as having between $100 million and $1 billion in annual revenues. While 
the range is broad, the firm’s legacy investments in the PRC, India, and Southeast Asia have been at the lower end 
of this range, with annual revenues between $100 million and $300 million. 

3  [This  information  has  been  removed  as  it  falls  under  the  exception  to  disclosure  in  ADB’s  Access  to  Information 

Policy, para. 17.2.(v)]. 

4  ADB will be investing in another Olympus Capital sponsored fund, Asia Environmental Partners II L.P. (AEP II), which 
is subject to board approval on 14 November 2014. AEP II is a separate environmental focused fund of Olympus 
Capital with a $300 million target commitment. 

 2  
 

 

access to clean air and water; structural imbalances in the supply chain and supply–demand for 
capital;  and  government  and  regulatory  policies  favorably  disposed  to  seeing  growth  and 
improvement in these sectors. 5 Olympus Capital will target Asian middle-market companies that 
benefit  from  a  combination  of  these  macroeconomic  trends,  including  agribusiness  and  food 
companies that improve the availability of and access to safe, quality food; financial intermediaries 
that provide business services and capital for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and 
consumers; and environmental services and clean energy companies that support environmental 
sustainability. 
 
6. 
The  fund  intends  to  invest  in  a  balanced  portfolio  of  10–15  established  and  growing 
middle-market  growth  companies,  with  a  focus  on  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC), 
Southeast Asia, India, as well as Japan and the Republic of Korea. 6 The average investment size 
will generally be between $50 million and $75 million each. Specified target segments will include 
the following: (i) for the agribusiness and food vertical, the upstream through midstream areas of 
the agriculture value chain; (ii) for the financial and business services vertical, consumer finance, 
structured credit, leasing and mortgages; and (iii) for the environmental vertical, renewable energy 
projects,  natural  gas  development  and  distribution,  waste  management,  and  energy  efficiency 
projects  and  services.  The  fund  will  generally  focus  on  providing  growth  capital  to  established 
middle-market companies on the verge of entering the next phase of growth. Olympus Capital will 
seek to become the largest shareholder or the largest outside shareholder alongside the investee 
company founder(s). The firm targets these control-oriented investments so that it can take an 
active management role in the portfolio company and implement value creating initiatives.  
 
C. 

Ownership, Management, and Governance 

1. 

Ownership 

7. 
The fund is a Cayman Islands exempted limited partnership that will comprise strategic 
investors, foundations, family offices, and other institutional investors. The Cayman Islands has 
been categorized largely compliant with internationally agreed tax standards in the latest progress 
report prepared by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development’s Global Forum 
on Transparency and Exchange of Information for Tax Purposes. 7 ADB’s review of the fund does 
not give ADB cause to believe that it has been established, or is being used for cross-border tax 
evasion, money laundering, or terrorism financing in the jurisdictions involved in the investment 
(footnote 1). 
 

 

2. 

Management 

8. 
The fund is sponsored by Olympus Capital, a leading independent private equity firm that 
has been investing in middle-market companies across Asia for over 17 years. [This information 
has been removed as it falls under the exception to disclosure in ADB’s Access to Information 
Policy, para. 17.2.(v)]. 
 

 

5  Sector Overview (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
6  Investments in ADB’s non-DMCs will be capped at 20% of the fund’s aggregate commitments and must demonstrate 
substantial  economic  linkage  with  ADB’s  DMCs.  In  case  an  investment  does  not  qualify  as  having  substantial 
economic linkage, ADB will have the right to opt out of the investment. 

7  Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. 2013. Tax Transparency 2013 Report on Progress. Paris. 
Other jurisdictions categorized largely compliant include Germany, the Netherlands, the United Kingdom, and the 
United States. 

  
 
 
 
9. 
Olympus Capital is led by a stable, senior investment team of eight highly experienced 
managing directors (including the three founders), who have an average tenure of 14 years with 
the firm. 8 The investment teams of the firm are organized by industry vertical, with two managing 
directors responsible for co-leading the firm’s efforts in each of the core sectors across Asia. The 
core sector teams comprise managing directors, executive directors, and vice-presidents, while 
the firm’s analysts and associates generally work across sectors and markets. Olympus Capital’s 
local teams throughout Asia allow it to execute deal sourcing and development, due diligence, 
and post-investment business plans on a local level. This provides significant benefits, particularly 
within the middle market, where local relationships and expertise are critical. 

3 

 
3. 

Governance Structure 

[This information has been removed as it falls under the exception to disclosure in ADB’s 

10. 
The  general  partner  will  follow  a  typical  three-stage  investment  process  based  on  an 
approach developed and refined through its 17 years of investing in middle-market companies in 
Asia: (i) investment screening of each potential portfolio company’s operations, products, market 
opportunity, and valuation against the fund’s mandate and strategy; (ii) deal structuring and due 
diligence; and (iii) preparation of investment proposals for presentation to the fund’s investment 
committee.  
 
11. 
Access to Information Policy, para. 17.2.(v)]. 
 
12. 
Access to Information Policy, para. 17.2.(v)]. 9 
  
13. 
As  an  investment  advisor  registered  with  the  United  States  Securities  and  Exchange 
Commission, Olympus Capital is required to comply fully with its provisions for combatting money 
laundering,  the  financing  of  terrorism,  and  anticorruption.  After  reviewing  Olympus  Capital’s 
policies to screen for integrity risks and combat money laundering and the financing of terrorism, 
ADB is satisfied that sufficient checks and screening measures are in place (footnote 1). ADB will 
require auditing of the implementation of such policies.  
 
D. 

[This information has been removed as it falls under the exception to disclosure in ADB’s 

Financial Performance 

[This information has been removed as it falls under the exception to disclosure in ADB’s 

14. 
Access to Information Policy, para. 17.2.(v)].  
 

III. 

THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 

A. 

The Assistance 

15. 
ADB will provide an equity investment of up to $40,000,000 in the fund, not to exceed 25% 
of the fund’s total capital commitments and not resulting in ADB being the single largest investor 
in the fund. 
 

8  [This  information  has  been  removed  as  it  falls  under  the  exception  to  disclosure  in  ADB’s  Access  to  Information 

9  [This  information  has  been  removed  as  it  falls  under  the  exception  to  disclosure  in  ADB’s  Access  to  Information 

 

Policy, para. 17.2.(v)]. 

Policy, para. 17.2.(v)]. 

 

 4  
 

 

B. 

Financial Analysis of Expected Returns and Assumptions  

[This information has been removed as it falls under the exception to disclosure in ADB’s 

16. 
Access to Information Policy, para. 17.2.(v)]. 10 
 
C. 

Implementation Arrangements 

1. 

Exit Strategy  

17. 
The fund has a 10-year term from final closing, with two options to extend for a maximum 
of  1  year  each.  Olympus  Capital  anticipates  that  the  principal  exit  strategies  for  the  fund’s 
investments will include both trade sales to strategic buyers, which have accounted for over 75% 
of  the  firm’s  realizations,  as  well  as  public  offerings.  Olympus  Capital  has  developed  a  strong 
discipline  around  proactive  exit  planning,  including  spending  a  significant  amount  of  time 
confirming alignment with management on the approach and timing of potential liquidity events, 
as well as structuring the investment with well-defined exit rights, including buyout options with 
counterparties, pre-agreed and seniority treatment in recapitalizations, post-initial public offering 
sales and dividend payouts, and drag-along or tag-along rights to deliver 100% or at least majority 
control to trade buyers. 
 

2. 

Reporting Arrangements 

18. 
The general partner will provide ADB with (i) quarterly unaudited reports; and (ii) audited 
annual reports, including financial statements, a fund overview, and an overview of the portfolio 
with brief information on each portfolio company’s performance and valuation. ADB will review 
this information and will follow up with the general partner when more information or clarification 
is needed. If the information received from the general partner raises issues that could impair the 
value of ADB’s investment in the fund, ADB will decide whether to put the fund on a watch list for 
more frequent review and closer attention. 
 
19. 
The general partner will be required to submit its environmental and social management 
system (ESMS) to ADB prior to its first disbursement and to report annually on environmental and 
social safeguards issues and development effectiveness indicators. ADB will monitor the receipt 
and quality of the ESMS reports and offer guidance should the general partner require clarification 
on ADB’s safeguard requirements. 
 
D. 

Value Added by ADB Assistance 

20. 
Capital mobilization. Given ADB’s presence and reputation in Asia, ADB’s participation 
as  an  anchor  investor  in  the fund  is  expected to  have  a  strong  signaling  effect—validating  the 
environmental and social governance framework and development impact against a backdrop of 
strong financial returns—and is a prime example of ADB’s Finance ++ concept of leveraging the 
institution’s reputation and capital to mobilize third-party investment activity in its DMCs. ADB’s 
investment  is  expected  to  mobilize  up  to  $75  million  in  additional  commitments  from  Asian 
institutional  investors,  as  well  as  a  similar  amount  from  co-investors  in  the  fund’s  portfolio 
companies.  
 

10  [This information  has  been  removed  as  it  falls  under  the  exception  to  disclosure  in  ADB’s  Access  to  Information 

Policy, para. 17.2.(v)]. 

 

  
 
 
 
21. 
Raising  standards.  ADB’s  presence  as  an  anchor  investor  in  the  fund  obligates  the 
general  partner  to  ensure  that  its  investee  companies  comply  with  environment  and  social 
safeguard  standards,  and  to  report  on  development  indicators.  ADB’s  role,  along  with  other 
members of the fund’s advisory committee, will be to assist in providing oversight on important 
governance matters that are critical for companies to demonstrate as they seek additional sources 
of growth capital from institutional and/or individual investors.

IV. 

DEVELOPMENT IMPACT AND STRATEGIC ALIGNMENT 

A. 

Development Impact, Outcome and Outputs 

1. 

Impact 

The impact is increased private equity funding in the Asian middle-market segment. The 
26. 
fund’s success is expected to catalyze additional private equity funding, including for the middle-
market segment, measured by the increase in private equity funding in Asia as a percentage of 
global private equity funding. 
 

2. 

Outcome 

27. 
The  development  outcome  of  the  fund  is  to  demonstrate  positive  social  and  financial 
returns through the private equity modality. At the conclusion of this project, the fund is envisaged 
to  exit  100%  of  its  investment  portfolio  at  a  minimum  net  IRR  of  8%,  with  at  least  75%  of  the 
investee  companies  demonstrating  some  measurable  improvement  in  the  availability  of  and 
access to safe and high-quality food; availability of capital to SMEs in urban and rural areas; or 
environmental  sustainability  (as  a  result  of  Olympus  Capital’s  value  addition).  The  fund  also 
expects  to  improve  the  corporate  governance  and  transparency  of  its  investee  companies, 
wherever possible, and to contribute to overall (i.e., net) job creation and tax contributions. 
 

3. 

Outputs 

28. 
The primary output is the establishment of a private equity fund focused on the middle-
income  segment  within  the  food  and  agribusiness,  financial  and  business  services,  and 
environmental sectors in Asia that mobilizes capital from a diversified base of Asian and western 
institutional and strategic investors. The fund will be considered successful if it achieves an initial 
closing by the first quarter of 2015, commences fund operations within 6 months of establishment, 

 

 6  
 

 

and deploys its capital within the 5-year proposed investment period from the fund’s final closing 
date. 
 
B. 

Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations  

1. 

Consistency with Strategy 2020  

29. 
In 2014, ADB completed the Midterm Review of Strategy 2020, which aimed to help the 
organization prepare for the challenges of transforming the Asia and Pacific region. This fund is 
consistent  with  the  review’s  emphasis  that  ADB  prioritize  support  for  inclusive  sectors  and 
environmentally sustainable projects. 11 Specifically, through investments in agriculture products 
that improve food security in Asia, the fund increases the availability of and access to quality food. 
The fund also supports financial sector development and the deepening of the financial sector by 
increasing the capacity of financial  intermediaries to  expand  lending  to SMEs  and  consumers, 
which  is  essential  to  ensuring  sustainable  private  sector-led  growth.  Finally,  the  fund  supports 
ADB’s climate change mandate by participating in clean energy investments.   
  

2. 

Consistency with Sector Strategy  

30. 
The  fund’s  investment  themes  align  well  with  ADB’s  agriculture,  energy  sector,  and 
financial  sector  strategies.  In  particular,  its  investments  in  agriculture  inputs  and  technologies 
support ADB’s Operational Plan for Sustainable Food Security, which recommends an expanded 
partnership with the private sector to attract more direct investments in productivity enhancement, 
agro-processing, agro-retailing, and other nonfarm rural business. 12  In addition, the fund’s clean 
energy projects are consistent with ADB’s Energy Policy, 13 which seeks to facilitate a transition 
to  a  low-carbon  economy  and  universal  access  to  energy  so  as  to  help DMCs  obtain reliable, 
adequate, and affordable energy for inclusive growth, and ADB’s Urban Operational Plan, which 
aims to promote more sustainable urban development through increased investments in water 
supply,  wastewater,  solid  waste,  and  energy  efficiency. 14 Further,  the  fund’s  investments  in 
financial  intermediaries  are  consistent  with  ADB’s  financial  sector  operational  plan,  which 
highlights  the  importance  of  support  for  SME  access  to  finance  as  part  of  financial  sector 
development,  and  the  need  to  support  the  three  key  pillars  of  the  real  economy:  households, 
SMEs, and infrastructure. 15    
 

3. 

Consistency with Country Strategy 

Interventions in ADB’s DMCs will be aligned with the relevant country strategies, including 
31. 
those of the PRC, India, Indonesia, Viet Nam, the Philippines, and Thailand, which consistently 
emphasize  private  sector  development,  sustainable  growth,  climate  change  mitigation  and 
adaptation, and clean energy as core themes. 
 

4. 

Lessons from Previous Operations

Access to Information Policy, para. 17.2.(v)].

A. 

Safeguards and Social Dimensions 

 

V. 

POLICY COMPLIANCE 

33. 
The fund will be required to comply with the applicable national laws and regulations, as 
well  as  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (SPS,  2009).  Under  the  SPS,  an  ESMS  has  to  be 
established  and  implemented  commensurate  with  the  impacts  and  risks  of  its  operations  and 
those  of  its  portfolio  companies.  The  fund  and  its  investee  companies  will  comply  with  the 
applicable laws and regulations on environment and health and safety, and it will not invest in any 
portfolio  company  that  conducts  or  is  involved  in  any  activity  on  ADB’s  prohibited  investment 
activities list. 16 Subprojects will be screened for risks and verified during due diligence. The fund’s 
ESMS will include provisions requiring the fund and its portfolio companies to comply with national 
labor laws and to take measures in relation to internationally recognized core labor standards, in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  social  protection  strategy. 17 The  project  is  categorized  as  having  no 
gender elements. 
 
34. 
Already identified pipeline opportunities for the fund include potential investments in a beef 
processing company, coffee manufacturing, business process outsourcing service solutions, and 
equipment leasing services. Each of these investments has its own occupational health and safety 
hazards, which can be avoided or mitigated by adhering to recognized international guidelines, 
best practices, and design criteria. The majority of the fund’s portfolio investments are likely to be 
classified category B or C. However, some environmental investments may be classified category 
A (e.g., involving irreversible impact on the project’s site biodiversity), for which SPS requirements 
for category A projects will be followed. Additional requirements may be set for category B portfolio 
investments  in  case  significant  gaps  exist  between  SPS  requirements  and  host  country 
regulations.  
 
On  social  safeguards,  the  investment  in  the  fund  is  classified  FI  for  environment, 
35. 
involuntary  resettlement,  and  indigenous  peoples  under  ADB’s  SPS.  While  the  majority  of  the 
fund’s investments are unlikely to involve involuntary resettlement or indigenous peoples impacts, 
such impacts are possible in some cases. These will be subject to the screening, due diligence, 
and  remedial  action  processes  set  out  in  the  ESMS  and  fund  documentation,  which  include 
compulsory referral of all investments categorized A for any impact to an environmental and social 
subcommittee,  on  which  ADB  will  have  the  right  to  participate.  In  addition,  ADB  will  seek  to 
negotiate with the general partner the right to opt out of, on a case-by-case basis, proposed fund 
investments categorized A or B for involuntary resettlement or indigenous peoples impacts. 
 
36. 
The fund will have an ESMS in place that complies with the SPS and details the policy, 
procedures, and workflow that will be followed for investments made by the fund. The ESMS will 
be an integral part of the fund’s investment process and will provide guidelines at the portfolio, 
company, and fund level, while requiring the fund to submit to ADB an annual environmental and 
social performance report documenting the continued compliance of its investee companies with 
ADB’s  environmental  and  social  performance  standards.  The  fund  will  hire  a  dedicated 
environmental management specialist with specific responsibilities in this area. 
 

16  ADB’s Prohibited Investment Activities List is in the Safeguard Policy Statement, Appendix 5. 
17  ADB. 2001. Social Protection. Manila. 

 

7 

 

 8  
 

 

B. 

Anticorruption Policy   

37. 
Olympus Capital, the general partner, and the investment manager were advised of ADB’s 
policy  of  implementing  best  international  practice  relating  to  combating  corruption,  money 
laundering,  and the financing  of terrorism.  ADB will  ensure  that  the  investment  documentation 
includes  appropriate  provisions  prohibiting  corruption,  money  laundering,  and  the  financing  of 
terrorism, and remedies for ADB in the event of noncompliance.   
 
C. 

Investment Limitations 

[This information has been removed as it falls under the exception to disclosure in ADB’s 

38. 
Access to Information Policy, para. 17.2.(v)]. 
 
D. 

Assurances 

Consistent with the Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank (the Charter), 18 
39. 
the governments of the PRC, India, and any other member country of ADB where the fund will 
invest  using  ADB  funds  will  be  requested  to  confirm  that  it  has  no  objection  to  the  proposed 
assistance  to  Olympus  Capital  Asia  V,  L.P.  Fund.  ADB  will  enter  into  suitable  finance 
documentation, in form and substance satisfactory to ADB, following approval of the proposed 
assistance by the Board of Directors.  
 

VI. 

RECOMMENDATION 

 
I  am  satisfied  that  the  proposed  equity  investment  would  comply  with  the  Articles  of 
40. 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the 
equity investment of up to $40,000,000 in Olympus Capital Asia V, LP Fund, from ADB’s ordinary 
capital resources, with such terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those 
set forth in this report, and as may be reported to the Board. 
 
 
 
 

 
 
November 2014 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Takehiko Nakao 
President 

18  ADB. 1966. Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank. Manila.

Social benefits:

Source: Asian Development Bank 
ADB = Asian Development Bank, ESMS = environmental and social management system, IPO = initial public offering, 
IRR = internal rate of return, Q = quarter. 
a  Defined broadly as investee companies having $100 million–$1 billion in revenues. 
b  For instance, national standards for food additives and food safety will be adhered to at a minimum. For the People’s 
Republic  of  China,  these  standards  include  GB2760  (2011)  for  Food  Additives  and  GB14880  for  Food  Safety. 
International  standards  for  food  safety  are  listed  in  CODEX  ALIMENTARIUS  –  International  Food  Standards. 
http://www.codexalimentarius.org/. Relevant indicators for financial services and environment will be chosen once 
the investments are identified. A list of indicators used by ADB’s private sector operations can be found in Annex 1 
of  its  Development  Effectiveness  Report.  http://www.adb.org/documents/development-effectiveness-report-2013-
private-sector-operations 

c   Relevant baseline and targets for improving corporate governance to be considered on a case-by-case basis, and 

targets (to be agreed) to be included in contractual agreements between the fund and investee companies. 

d   The role of the advisory committee is to represent the interest of the fund’s investors and provide oversight to the 
fund’s  operational  activities,  including  opining  on  potential  conflicts  of  interest  and  issues  related  to  fund 
governance.  The  advisory  committee  will  not  participate  in  the  fund’s  investment  process  or  make  investment 
decisions.
